creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund; purchase from the collection of Elizabeth and Willard Clark
description: seven frogs: two frogs at center engaged in wrestling match, with frog at L leaping with arms sprawled; frog at R rolling onto back with wide grimace on face; two frogs with worried looks observing at L; three angry looking frogs watching at R
signed: L edge: 法橋周峯貴信写 {Hokkyō Shūhō Takanobu sha}
text: On a damp and rainy day, a bunch of frogs are enjoying themselves with sumo wrestling. While two frogs are engaged in a bout, other frogs are sitting on the left and right to watch them while they hold their big round bellies. Each frog expresses a striking individuality, creating a richly humorous impression. Personification of frogs in human activities has been used in Japan since the Heian period (794–1180).
title: Frogs in Sumo Match
